sp.p: By Heaven, I know not, Sir, unless some hidden flame for thee—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It cannot be, I never saw a glance, a look, or smile, cou'd be suspected Love: 'tis some old Grudge. Dear, do not follow him, my heart presages something that is fatal. [weeps.] Good Sir perswade him. To Sir Lyon.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Away, ye fool, perswade him not to fight! away, a Coward! hang't, he were not worth thy love then.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Honour, my Deer, obliges me to go. Wou'dst have the man that has thy heart in keeping, be pointed out for Cowardize? Away, thou needst not fear, we shall at most onely exchange a Wound. Thy sacred Image guards my heart entire, and keeps it safe from danger. Go to the Banquet, entertain the Ladies, and be merrie.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: By Cocks bones shall she, and be very merrie, to think she's like to have so brisk a Spark to her Bed-fellow. Go thy ways, William, and God's blessing go with thee, Boy: if thou wants a second, I can push yet, I'm not so old efaith.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I humbly thank ye, Sir; we shall think better on't perhaps before we fight.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Or shall Sir John go? he's a man of mettle, I assure you, Brother.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What the Devil do ye mean! I have mind to take this opportunitie to be with thee, thou little wanton—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Fear not, Sir, I'll excuse ye.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You little amiable mischievous Ape you, what a seurvie malicious Jest did you break upon me, to make the Proverb good, You had rather lose your Friend than your Jest?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: A Jest! it was a parlous true one then: I said you were all Mettle; A brazen face, a leaden brain, and a copper nose and beard.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Wit, Lightning, and Quick-silver, thou little more than Dwarf, and something less than woman.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: A Wasp, a Wasp! Your Wit stings, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Thou'rt plaguie sharp; pray God thou be'st not too far gone in Love; if thou shou'dst, I must be forc'd in honour to marrie thee, tho introth't wou'd be hardly brought about.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p:
No matter, Sir; things got by strugling, bring the greater pleasure, when dull Consent but palls the Appetite. Then thou'rt a fool too, the most admirable necessary for a Husband in
the whole Creation, and the best Block to carve a Cuckold in.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Whe, what a tart Monkey's this! By my troth if thou hadst not so much wit, I cou'd finde in my heart to take thee for better for worse; for I finde thou cou'dst bear me with all my faults.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Bear with thee! I wonder how thy Mother bore thee nine whole months about her, when I'll be sworn I can scarce endure thee in my sight an hour.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Alas for you, sweet Soul, good lack! A pox of your Wit: By the Lord Harry, you are the proudest, scoffing, scurvie, idle, fantastical, whimsical— Ads nigs, because you have read St. George for England, Amades de Gall, and the Legend of Lyes, you are licens'd, forsooth, to abuse all the world: Egad, Sir Lyonell, your Father shall know't.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: He must not tho— Nay, do not go in Rancor, good dear Knight; for I must confess a secret to you; which if you knew my heart, you wou'd believe there were nothing so cruel there as you imagine. I speak very kinde things of you between my Maid and I anight as I am going to bed, and next my Prayers too, Heaven forgive me! I spoke things of you that I wou'd not wish you shou'd know.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Nay, look ye, for my part, if I have not most religiously vow'd my heart yours, been drunk twice a day to your health, swallow'd Fire and inches of your Cuff-strings, eat Candles, pledg'd your health in Chamber-lie, run Pins into my Arms, and done all manner of gallant and heroick actions, I'm the veriest son of a Whore breathing; and yet to tell me after all this, I have a brazen face, a leaden brain, and a copper nose, [weeps.] 'tis most intolerable, insupportable, and prodigious, I'll be sworn.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: And de ye love me so indeed?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Love you! 'Sbud, whosoever says I do not, and honour you too, Egad; nay, and if you wou'd, wou'd marrie you, is a son of a Whore, and a Scoundrel, by the Lord.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: And let me tell you in return, that— Heaven forgive me! And my Sister knows I have took drink and slept upon't, that if ever I marrie, it shall be you; and I will marrie, and yet I hope I do not say it shall be you neither. Come, let's to the Banquet.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
Oh, dear Creature, I do not say you do: Lord, how was I mistaken in thy heart! But will you hereafter cast a kinde
look at me, to put me in countenance before Companie? That I wou'd be at now.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Much may be done. Come, let's to the Banquet.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And will you, my prettie little Darling of mine eyes, marrie me? As I hope to breath, my Purse, Bodie, Soul and all, shall be thine.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Most affectionately spoken! Well, get my Fathers consent, and as for mine— the Devil take me if ever thou gets it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: A Kiss, and 'tis a Match. Thus Hymen shou'd begin; A falling out, sometimes proves falling in.

div.stage: Enter Wellman and Friendly, as in the street.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Well, my dear friend, tell me with open heart, hath not my Reasoning reclaim'd thy Folly, preserv'd thy falling Vertue, and secur'd it?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: There is no Vertue in Blood, no Reasoning in Desire: But shall I not in this fond act of Love, do that which will to thee render my name abhorr'd, and make thee hate me?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: By Heaven, no.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And shall I then? may I enjoy Corina?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Thou shalt, by all our Friendships. Here, take this Ring, shew it to that fair Devil, it will confirm me dead; which rumour, with my absence, will make good— Possess thy Love, grow wearie in her Arms, then be thy self again.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: But if Report grows strong, and I am seiz'd, where shall I finde thee?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: At Glistens my Goldsmith in Cheapside, to whom I'll tell our business and designe.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Thither I'll come and tell thee how I thrive. Till when, farewel.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: When woman's in 〈◊〉 heart, the soul's all hell. Now Repentance, the after-clap of Fools, light on thee; I have an Art left that may reclaim thee yet. I'll make thee fall into the vilest dangers, even worse than womans Lust. No Goldsmith will I see, or tell my storie to, but in some sit disguise I'll hide my self impossible to be discover'd, and leave thee to two friends, a Whore and Law, that will be plague sufficient for one man; but is this friendship in me? [pawses.] No matter:
No man is purely vertuous, no Vertue purely kind;
The end being good, the way is well design'd.

div.head: SCENE changes to Corina's house.
div.stage: Enter Corina in anger, followed by Trickwell with Plate, and Mrs. Dunwell.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Oh, impudence, am I then fallen so low to be sollicited by Pimps and Panders! Hell take the trade, if this be the effects on't.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Madam, whatever you may think of me, my Present has the shew of Qualitie; here's Plate, a Present that a Lord might make ye; and I was once a Gentleman, tho I am fallen so low by faithless Vice, yet tho undone, poor and depriv'd of all, I have a heart and will, that still remains, and fain wou'd venture on when Beautie calls. And if I have a stock, which Heaven and my own industrie has lent, I must employ it still to that dear use. Take first this little Tribute of my conquer'd heart; I may in time increase it: were it Crowns, here they shou'd all be offer'd.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: And thus I'd spurn away: Base servile Villain, who livest by Noise and Riot, spunging upon the drops that fall from Gentlemen, canst thou believe that after Wellman's love, I cou'd receive a Raskal to my Arms?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: If I were there, you'd finde but little difference; and possibly the next they entertain may fail to pay this price I offer ye. This Raskal and that beautious haughtie thing, bating the Sex, differ but very little. I live by Brauls, by rapine, and by Spoils, in Fears, Vexations, Dangers, so do you; I eat when I can get a fool to treat me, and you can do no more: Pox of your pride, methinks we two might understand each other; you've no Gallant to take your Quarrels up; you raign'd when time was, and I'll do so now, for you have known my love, shall finde my power, tho yet I nere durst tell you so.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Nor shall not yet; for tho that Lover's gone, who but to look on wou'd have made thee tremble, I've Beautie still that may command another Beautie whose very glance shou'd make thee bow: Gods! and has it lost its awe?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: It has, and I'm resolv'd upon a Conquest.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
Death, Sirra! stand off, and view my fatal hand, it carries death to the bold Ravisher, that dares approach unreverendly. A Whore! what tho to her that bears it 'tis a shame, an infamie that cannot be supported? to all the world besides it bears a mightie sound, petition'd, su'd to, worshipp'd as a God, presented,
flatter'd, follow'd, sacrific'd to, Monarch of Monarchs, Tyrant of the world, what does that charming word not signifie! And darest thou raise thy hated eyes so high to gaze on such a Constellation! No, be gone, with all thy base-got worthless Trisles, quickly pack up, and hence, or I will kill thee.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: So, Sir, you had better have lookt no higher than Mrs. Mary Dunwell, who can down with you when money's low; but when once a little in Pocket, you are for high feeding, forsooth. Go get you gone, I may chance take pitie on you when her passion's over, and do you some service.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No, by Heaven, I'll try my chance this very minute, throw my last Cast, for the great Stake is set, and will enjoy her now.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Hah! here's somebodie I hope will interrupt you.
What wou'd you, Sir? wou'd you have ought with me? A proper handsome fellow, but ill drest.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Madam, I am a Gentleman grown poor, decay'd by fortune, and wou'd gladly serve: I can obey, cou'd you direct me where.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: This fellow wou'd serve my turn most admirably! but if I cou'd— you wou'd grow proud with feeding well and clean Linnen.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I am not bred so ill, but I can tell how to be grateful to you.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Introth he apprehends most discreetly— but you're too big to wear a Liverie.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Not at all; 'tis the fashion now for Ladies to keep tall men in Liveries: your Page is out of fashion, and your stripling Footman.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: [within] Help! help! undone! Oh help!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Hah, what noise is that!

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Heavens! the Rogue sure was ravishing her.

div.stage: Enter Wellman dragging in Trickwell, Corina follows disordered.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Damn'd sawcie Villain, what was thy pretence?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What's that to thee, bold interrupting Slave, sent by the Devil to hinder my delight?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Dog—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Hold, do not kill the Raskal; 'tis enough you've sav'd me from his mischiefs: pray let him go.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: 'Tis pitie, but I will obey. Take that, and that, that, ye Mungrel Cur; Dogs shou'd be us'd so. [Kicks him out.] Death! what a very wretched thing's a Whore, that every Raskal dares approach with Love!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Who are ye, pray, to whom I'm so oblig'd?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: One that wou'd gladly serve in any qualitie.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I'll do thee good; take that. [Gives him money.] I will prefer thee to some man of Qualitie: Mean time make this your home.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I wonder whether Friendly has been here!

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Madam, one knocks; shall any have admittance?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Onely false Wellman's Friend. You may retire, and wait my farther pleasure.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I'll over-hear ye too.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Now, my dear Mistriss, Soul of my desires, I come with all the Spoils of conquering Love, to lay 'em at thy feet. My Stop is dead, the Stop of all my ravishing Happiness; and here's the witness of my Victorie.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Dead! Wellman dead! Oh thou inhumane friend, that borest that title onely to betray him! Dead! and by thee! Heaven, can you let him live! Support me, or I fall to earth with this sad killing news.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Heavens, Madam, what d'ye mean? or shall I vow to you he is not dead?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Hah! not dead!

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What wou'd you have me do? When I confirm him dead, you grow inrag'd; and when I say he lives, you kill with frowns.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Traytor, and hast thou then deceiv'd my hopes? and is not Wellman dead? Hell, what is man! how didst thou swear, how didst thou prostrate lie, and beg'd to give me any proof of thy false Passion? I ask'd thee this; and is it thus you give it! Oh for a quick revenging Power to kill thee!

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Calm that dear angrie face, and tell my Love which way it best shall please.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
Is't in thy choice, perjur'd, forsworn, and false, to tell me either? Damn thy double Tongue, and all this Beautie that
mis-led thy truth, if thou hadst ever any in thy soul.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Then since it is my destinie to offend, which way soere I take I'll follow truth, and tell you, Madam, all your strict Commands I did obey, and Wellman is no more.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No more! why what hadst thou to do with my Commands? Oh thou hast kill'd all that my soul cou'd love! Tho I commanded, yet he was thy friend, and that in generositie shou'd have sav'd him. Go from my eyes, far from my thoughts remain.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Is this then the reward of all my Love? What have I done, but been obedient? Had I priz'd my Friendship above that Love, wou'd you have took it well? Yes, I will be gone, and to the judging world
Prove who's the greater Criminal you or I:
I kill'd a Friend, you make a Lover die.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I must not let him go, till I'm reveng'd. Stay, I relent; Oh stay, and give my heart a little time to take leave of its old acquaintance, ere it'go to make a new and unknown choice agen. Alas, I lov'd this Wellman, lov'd him dearly, more than my life.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why did you kill him then?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Why, in my own defence; he gave the first, I fear the mortal wound.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Then think it just, and think of him no more, but of the dear reward you are to give for all my service. Come, will you not?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I will; but you'll receive it decently, and not with hands distain'd i'th'blood of him that lately was so dear to me?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Still on that subject? do not put me off; I've left the business of my life undone, and had not power to go about my Pardon, so hastie for the dear reward I was; and is it thus you treat me?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You'll finde me all you wish, give me an hours time to compose my self; and all this upon my brow is but a modest decencie; one hour of joy will chase it all away.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Do not you dally with me?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No by Heaven, when you return I'll give ye your reward, and what you most deserve— a Halter 'tis, [Aside.] false and perfidious wretch.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Here, keep this Ring, and think each minutes absence is a long year in love. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Farewel, vain credulous treacherous fool, farewel. Mischief inspire me now with all your Arts; methinks the sight of this instructs my Soul in a most noble piece of Villanie: I will to fair Marinda with this Ring, and frame a storie of so cunning mischief, shall stab her through the ear into the heart. By Heaven, 'tis greatly brave, and I'll begin it: Then when this false believer does return, I'll be prepar'd for him— What, Hoe, who waits?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Now what a Devil is this woman grown!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: My Hoods and Fan, and call a Coach immediately: [Exit Dun.] and you, Sir, I must beg to wait on me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Where ever you command.— This was happie!

div.head: SCENE changes to Sir Lyonell's house.
div.stage: Enter Sir Lyonell, Marinda, Diana and Maid, and Sir John.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, good Sir, be not angrie that I sent; I was afraid some harm wou'd come of it, and so I fear there is.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: And did no one hear of him?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: None; pray Heaven he be well; my heart misgives me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Well, if he be lost, there's a brave fellow gone, and in a time the King had need of Souldiers; there's idle Husbands enough for you, Baggages.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: I have a little kind of a scurvie pain too, which I do not use to feel about my heart, for Friendly— but none shall see it in my troubled looks: not that I care who knew the loving secret, but I'll not be laught at.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Leave your whimpering, do: Wou'd thou hadst a heart like thy Sister here. When wou'd she cry for a man thus?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, when I have as much need of a man as she, that is, when I want one, I cannot dissemble.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Look ye, Sir, she has need enough, and thanks to fortune she's provided for, with your good liking, noble Sir Lyonell.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Come, Sir, let's have one Marriage well over, before we think of another. Wou'd we cou'd hear of these Sparks too; 'tis almost midnight: they might have staid till day-light, and have kill'd one another like Christians decently, not by dark, as Cats and Dogs worrie each other. I know not what to think on't.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Here's a Ladie in a Coach below desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: A Ladie at this hour! she shall be welcome; old as I am, I'll not deny a Ladie.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: I hope your business is with me, fair Ladie.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: 'Twou'd be but ill dispatch'd then.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I know not, Sir; first let me crave your name, or are you Father to the fair Marinda?

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: I am, fair Mistriss, for want of a better. By the Mass she's very handsome! [aside.] This is the Maid you name.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: My time's but short, and what I have to say I must dispatch. Madam, you had a Lover once, Young Wellman!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Had! (good Heavens!) I hope and have.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No, Friendly has basely kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh wretched lost Marinda!

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Look to my Daughter!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Madam, look up; this great concern he merits not: 'twas pitie brought me here to undeceive ye; his Vows and Soul were mine, intirely mine.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why didst thou call me back to life again, or say in pitie that you undeceiv'd me? If you knew Wellman false, why did you stay me? You shou'd have let me di'd, 't had been more charitable; but if, as you affirm, he lov'd you best, which I believe from that fair form of yours, whilst I remain I needs must love you too.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: This must be malice sure!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Madam, do ye know this Ring? he gave it me, and told me such things of your tiresome Passion, as gave us cause of laughter all the evening.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I cannot blame him that he lov'd me not, when so much Beautie as appears in you, gave him permission to adore it: but methinks 'twas ungentile to make a sport of me; he shou'd have pitied follies he created: he lov'd me first; alas, I sought him not. [weeps.] Help me, Diana, for I feeble grow! To morrow shou'd have been my Wedding-day, now I invite you to my Funeral; bring Flowers and strow the way to my cold Grave, and lay me down in peace.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Lead her in, and be careful of her; but, Madam—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I cannot hold, I must reveal my self; [going stops] Yet stay, Heavens, shall I suffer her to die▪ so good, so gentle, and so sweet a Mistriss? Were there but three such women in the world, two might be sav'd.— Yes, I'll have patience yet to see the utmost that this Devil aims at.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Confest it, said ye, Madam? and to you? on what Acquaintance, pray?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: He was in love with me; and seeing no hope of gaining me whilst Wellman was alive, he pick'd a Quarrel with him, and dispatch'd him, and vaunted of the Villanie to me. Please you to go where I'll direct you, Sir, he shall confess the Murder.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Madam, I'll go; and you, Sir John must bear me companie.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Madam, your hand. Roger, go you to Mr. Constable, bid him be readie if I have occasion, and careful who passes the streets to night.

div.head: SCENE the Street.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Sayst thou, Sam, at one Mrs. Dunwell's house? whe, she's a Bawd.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, or my intelligence is false. There lies a Ladie, Sir, with whom he's desperately in love; and having no purchase-money, 'tis thought, hires the Bawd at the price of's own bodie, to get the young Ladie, Sir: They call her Corina.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Lord, Lord, what will this wicked world come to! And there thou sayest I may be sure to finde this villanous Trickwell.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: He never lies from thence all day, Sir, as I am inform'd; 'tis now about his hour of departure, and this way he must come.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Get ye home, Sam; I'll ene take Mr. Constable and a Watchman or two, and fall to searching. Get ye home, Sam, thou shalt have a new Sute for this, honest Sam. [Exit Sam. Well, if I catch the Rogue, he shall be hang'd in lousie linnen: I'll hire a Priest to make a Papist of him before Execution; and when he's dead, I'll piss on's Grave.—
But stay, who comes here? this may be he.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Damn this Corina, this proud scornful Beautie, whom I must humble and enjoy. I know I am a Rogue not worthie of her love, a Raskal that have no one Good about me, but that I love: And this damn'd Bawd, to keep me to her self, disgraces me to Corina.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Aye, aye, this must be he— Ware shaving, Sir: What ho, the Watch! the Watch! Takes hold of Trickwell ' s Cloak.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Death! 'tis Dashit's voice! [Gets from him, and runs out, leaving his Cloak behinde with Dashit.
Thieves! Thieves! stop Thieves!

div.stage: Enter the Watch after, met by Trickwell.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Who goes there? come before the Constable.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Death, you are a prettie fellow of a Constable, to represent the King's Person indeed! here's a Watch for the Devil! honest men are robb'd under your Noses. A Raskal in the habit of a Vintner set upon me, cri'd stand and deliver, in the Kings Highway; he wou'd have had my Purse, but that my heels sav'd it: Yet he got my Cloak of rich Camlet, I'll be sworn, new and fair this morning. If you light on him, seize him, and keep him in the Stocks till the Cloak will hang him.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Doubt not our diligence, Master, these dangerous times.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: Something to drink, Master, we that take pains for the good of the Nation.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Honest men, watch and sleep not. Good night.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: Well, Master, we must watch better indeed. Is't not strange that Knaves, Rogues, and Thieves, shou'd be abroad, and yet we of the Watch, Scrivenors, Exchange-men, and Taylors, never stir a foot!

div.stage: Enter Dashit running with the Cloak.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: An honest man and a Citizen.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: The Knave's drunk, and speaks Riddles.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Come afore the Constable; what art thou?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: A Vintner.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Bring him neer: Hah, what's here, the Cloak?

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Vintner! is't you? Hold, a rich Camlet-Cloak; 'tis the same.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Oh thou Varlet, does not thou know the Wicked cannot scape the eyes of the Constable?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What means all this? as I'm an honest man and a Citizen, I took the Cloak—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: As you're a Knave, you took the Cloak; we are your witnesses for that.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: But, Neighbours, hear me, hear who I am.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: A Thief you are, we know.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: My name is Dashit.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I, I, we'll dash ye: in with him to the Stocks there, and lock him fast till morning, that Justice Lackbrain may examine him.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Whe, but heark ye—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Mr. Constable—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: In, I say.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Am I not stark mad yet, not quite an Ass?

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: You may be in good time, in grace a God, Sir. Well, what wou'd this Citie do, if 'twere not for-such necessarie Tyrants as our selves to ride the free-born Jades, and humble 'em?

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.p: Prithee hold thy prating, minde our-duties, and let's go sleep in the fear of the Lord.

div.stage: [Ex. all but Dash. in the Stocks.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Who's there? So ho! so ho! [to him Trick. like a Bell-man. I shall be mad, lose my wits, and then be hang'd. Who goes there I say? thou mayst approach without fear, I'm fast by the heels.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.l: 'Tis Dashit!
Maids in your Night-rails,
Look to your light Tails,
Keep close your Locks,
And down your Smocks;
Keep a broad Eye,
And a close Thigh.
sp.p: Good morrow, my Masters all, good morrow.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: A Pox of Eyes and Thighs! Whe, Bell-man.

div.stage: [Trick. comes to him, holds his Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: [Through the Nose.] Good lack, good lack, Mr. Dashit! whe, what does your Worship in the Stocks? pray come out, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Out, Sir! whe, I tell thee I am lockt.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Lockt! Oh Men, Oh Manners! Oh Times, Oh Night! that canst not discern gravitie and wisdom, in one of the Common-Council too! Whe, what's your Worship in for?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: For? a Plague on't, suspition of Felonie.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Nay, an't be such a trifle, Lord, I cou'd weep to see your good Worship in this taking: Your Worship has been a good friend to me; and tho you have forgot me, I have found your Worship's doors open, and I have knockt, and God knows what I have sav'd; and do I live to see your Worship stockt?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Hah! alas, honest man, thou knows me then: Prithee call the Watch, and let the Constable know who I am, prithee do; and here, I have some money about me.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: 'Tis more than I deserve, Sir; let me alone for your deliverie.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Do so, honest Bell-man, and then let me alone with that Knave Trickwell.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Maids in your Night-rails, &c.
sp.stage: Going out, enter Constable and Watch.
sp.p: Mr. Constable, who's in the Stocks?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: One Dashit, for a Robberie. Dashit he calls himself: dost know him?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Know him!— Well, Mr. Constable, what good have you done the Citie! Know him! a most notorious Thief; his house has been suspected for a Bawdie-house many a year; a harbourer of Cut-purses and Night-walkers; he has been a long time in the black blook, and is he taken now?

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.p: How? Burladie, Neighbour, we'll not trust the Stocks with him; we'll to Newgate with him to rights.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Well mov'd, Simon. Come, Sir, come, Sir, out with him.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh, does your Raskalships know me now? I thought you wou'd know me in the end.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yes, the end of your worship we know.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Aye, here's an honest fellow can inform ye.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yes, we thank him, he has inform'd us you are a Pimp and a Thief. Binde him fast, and to Newgate with him.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: To Newgate! why Bell-man, Rogue, Raskal? To Newgate, amongst the prophane Jesuits too? oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: So, thou art like to thrive in thy Knaverie: Roguerie prospers with thee. To morrow is the Sessions at the Old-baily; I'll make him shrink with fear, ere I have done. Cou'd I but be reveng'd on this Corina,
I shou'd be prosperous indeed;
Some little Devil help me at a pinch at need.

div.head: SCENE the First. Corina's House.
div.stage: Enter Sir Lyonel, Sir John, Corina and Wellman, disguis'd.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: THis is my Lodging, Gentlemen; where, if you'l please to wait a little, you shall both see and hear the truth of what I've told you.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: But, Madam, Did he tell you he had kill'd his Friend? tell you himself, 'tis strange!

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Sir, If you find I wrong him, let me dye. He came all breathless, panting to my Chamber, his Sword all bloody, pray'd me to conceal him, for he had murder'd Wellman.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Under favour, Madam, what quarrel had they, said he, 'tis a most rare Creature, I'm half in Love already.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Innocently was the unhappy cause; they lov'd me, both were Rivals in my Favour, nor knew I which my heart inclin'd to most; Wellman had Wit, Youth, Gaity and good Humour, lovely, well made, fit to engage a heart; and Friendly too was handsom, very discreet, very Amorous, soft in his Language, modest in his Actions; and tho' their Charms were different, yet 'twas hard to say who was the greater Conquerour; so I by favouring both, made either jealous.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: S'bud, wou'd I had shar'd of that without the danger?

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: But Wellman was to have married my Daughter Marinda; to morrow was the day.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: To please his Father, Sir, he made you think so, he has oft with sighs to me confess'd he could not love Marinda, I hope she will believe, and dye in rage, and then I shou'd lye contented in my Grave.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: I pity thee, in troth now; but he was such a Villain, that but for his Fathers sake I'd let him dye unreveng'd— but Sir Jeffery Wellman's my Friend, and therefore I'l be dispos'd by you.

sp.speaker: Dunw.
sp.p: Madam, here's the Villainous man come— as gay as a young Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Pray Sir retire with these Gentlemen into my Closet, and you shall hear he will confess the murder, and having witness, you may apprehend him, and do you the while prepare the Watch, and let 'em wait below.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: With what a Fury is a Whore inrag'd?

div.stage: [Puts Sir Lyonel and Sir John into the Closet, and Wellman and Dunwell go out.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: So now my Revenge grows high, cou'd I but hang this Friendly, which I wou'd because 'twas Wellman's Friend, and make Marinda mad,
Oh! with what Joy I'd follow— for 'tis I
Must end the last Act of the Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Now, my Corina, now, my Heavenly Fair,
I come to take that Joy which from thy Eyes
I find thou wilt allow my panting heart—
And here upon my knees receive my Vow;
If ever I prove false to so much Beauty
May I be ever scorn'd by Men and Heaven!
Oh! the excessive Joy that fills my Soul
With thought of my approaching happiness.
Come, lets draw nearer to our bliss, thy Chamber—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: But stay—

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Oh! do not kill me with that fatal stay.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You have not told me yet how you kill'd Wellman.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Oh! name him not, some fit of Love or Rage will seize thy Soul at naming him, and ruin me. My dear Corina, Mistris of my Life, name him no more.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Now, on thy Life, by all I hold most dear, now Wellman is no more, the repetition will be wondrous grateful. Prethee, how fell the perjur'd faithless man? tell it me o're agen, and I'll resign my self for ever to thy Arms.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Tell thee and take thee! Were each word Blasphemy, wou'd every Syllable betray my Life, I'de hast to utter it for that Reward: though I can tell no more than what I've done already— that we met at a Ball, prepar'd for the contracting of Wellman to Marinda; where I being out in a Dance, or I at least pretending so, I struck him, we drew, but being parted there, I challeng'd him out, and it being late, we fought i'th street, where I had th' Advantage of him and kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: What did you with the Body?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Drag'd it into Fleet Ditch, with the next Tide to flote where Fortune pleas'd, and slew my dear Corina—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You shall dye for't, fond easie Fool—

div.stage: Enter Sir Lyonel, Sir John, and lay hold of him: Wellman from below with Officers.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Seize the Murderer, Oh wicked Villain, base and treacherous!

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Base and perfidious Woman! hold off your hands, and let me ask this Devil, why she does thus.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ah fool! that cou'dst believe my Love so slight to let thee live, that murder'd him I liv'd for.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Well ye Gods! you have reclaim'd my Wildness, and brought me back to man,— and now I see the Strong Deformity of sinful Passion.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Come, Come, Sir, we came not here to talk, 'tis Morning already, carry him directly to the Old Baily, the Sessions is now, and let him be hang'd out of the way.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: You've Reason Sir, and deserve this Usage, but yet unhand me— thus I'de been serv'd had I indeed kill'd Wellman! but Sir he lives, lives at his Goldsmiths, one Glister in Cheapside.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Heavens! Lives! Lives to be married! Oh—

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: We are not to believe that Sir, to Prison with him till▪ he can prove this true.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: No rudeness Sir, I'll go unguarded— Death! what a vile, poor, degenerate thing, a Mercenary Woman is—

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: How, a Mercenary Woman? Where the Devil have I liv'd, and how past my time, I knew her not before— this is her Man— I must get acquainted with him,— Friend— a Word I pray.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: How Sir, this Woman set you on! nay then Mr. Constable, pray lay hold of her, and see her forth coming.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: With Joy, since Wellman lives, and lives to be perjur'd, no matter what becomes of poor lost me.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: No Sir, let me instruct you, take my Word I am a Gentleman, and known to you, she shall be forth coming if there be an Occasion, tho' she be false she is a Woman still, a beauteous lovely Woman— come Sir I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I've yet a little Pity on my Heart, and that forsaken Beauty I have ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: But Sir you do not mind me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Said you Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: I ask'd you Sir, who this Lady was, to whom I perceive you belong; whether a man may be welcome for his Money— you conceive me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Nay Sir, I ask your Pardon Sir, no Offence I hope; I'am a Knight by Birth Sir, and have Sir, some sixteen hundred a year Sir, no contemptable Fortune for a Gallant.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: A Gallant Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Whe yes Sir, a Gallant Sir, whe what a Devil, I speak no Treason I hope in the Lord.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: But Sir you do as bad, this Lady is of Quality, and has a Fortune too, or if she had not, she has Beauty sufficient to intitle her to be a wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Say you so Friend, I must confess I am very much taken with her Beauty, but that I have a sort of an Ingagement upon my Person, to Mrs. Diana now, but I like this better by much Sir; and if she can but clear her self of the Business of this Murder, and has but any reasonable Fortune— and I get my self off this Diana—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Who is she Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Sir Lyonel Worthy's Daughter Sir, a little learing Titt as any's in England.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Sir to serve you, cou'd you help me to the Speech of her, I wou'd do much, and have some artful Cunning.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p:
Help thee, whe I'll carry thee immediately man, but do't so, as she may be very willing to part with me— or
else, poor thing, twill grieve me to disappoint her.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I'll warrant you for doing that; and clearing this Lady, and securing you a Portion.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: E Gad, and I'm a Man made then— come along thou shalt have a handsom Reward for thy Pains too.

div.head: SCENE Sir Lyonel's House
div.stage: Enter Marinda, and Diana, and Maid.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But Sister is't a Sin to hang one's self?
Is it a Crime to dye when Life's a Torment?
Methinks Heaven shou'd forgive it.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Prethee leave these Disputes, ye make me sad,
A Humour that I hate, and yet for Friendly,
I've try'd to weep and sigh, and have attain'd to't
With very much adoe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh thou art happy, wou'd I were unconcern'd,
An even brutal Temper that no Miseries
Cou'd touch, nor Mirth cou'd elevate.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Call you that brutal, give me that solid one;
I hate your thin and unsubstantial Soul
That every ject or small Assault of Grief,
Breaks through and makes ridiculous Mirth and Rage,
For every petty accident: Give me a Soul,
A Humour that's in Grain, not one that
Fades like Colours in the Sun, and changes like
Your Cheeks now pale, now red, and tells the World
The Secrets of your Heart; and yet I must confess I'm
Griev'd for Friendly, for you know I lov'd him,
Yet not so much to whine or dye for him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis true, when I consider he was false, methinks I should not dye.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p:
Nay, as for that I think you are mistaken, I believe him true enough, and that was some insensed Mistris, some of his Family of Love, that envyed your Happiness only, and came to put you in Despair, and I believe Wellman is not dead, nor can
I think Friendly cou'd be so base upon any account to kill him; he's virtuous, has some Religion in him, and much honesty, prethee be pacified; come sit, you have not slept to night, sit and lets sing to you, and I dare hold you my Diamond Pendants to fifty Guinneys Wellman is alive. Come Ample, sing a Song.

div.stage: Enter Wellman and Sir John at the door.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Look ye, Sir, I have brought you in, now lay your lyes as close together as you please, do you my bus'ness, and no matter how: I must to the Sessions house this morning to give my Evidence against Friendly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Away! I'll hear no more! I cannot sleep! Alas, there is no Musick like my sighs and grones; leave me, and let me go— to rest, and Wellman!

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Ample, she swoons, help, help—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: By your leave, sweet Creatures.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Uncivil Sir, what are you?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: One that brings comfort: hah! the Lady dying! stand off, I have a Cordial in my Voice— oh! she's gone, curs'd be my Trial! See, 'tis Wellman calls.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Wellman! ha, ha, ha! Sister, look up, he's here.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: She stirs, give her more Air.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How have I slip'd off Life! where am I, hah! in Heaven sure, and this is Wellman kneeling: Art thou an Angel there?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I would not wish it yet, no; we have an Age to come in love e're we arrive to that.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You live then! [softly] I shall dy with Joy else.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Call back the Blood into thy paled Cheeks, thou Miracle of Women! I made this tryal only to secure my Faith, and I believe you love, and I am happy; by all that's good, I never was unjust; that Woman, that beauteous Sinner whom you saw, I've been to blame with, but you must forgive the Errours of my Youth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I do! and her! and must love whom you've lov'd.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I thank thy goodness, but it shall not need, hereafter I'll tell thee all my Life, but now my time is short, and I must yet remain in this Disguise 'till Friendly's Tryal's past; for he shall suffer to the last degree, for leaving thee, Diana, for another.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: And has he been so wicked?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Yes, but is now reclaim'd, but 'twas but in obedience to your Commands, you'd have him try to lose his Maidenhead, and he forsooth fell desperately in love, but I'll return the Penitent into your Arms again.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.p: Faith Brother, I do love the Fugitive, that's flat: and if my Father please, will marry him; but he's for Sir John Empty.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: But Sir John Empty is not for you, his heart's ingag'd to this Corina, my quondam Mistris, she strikes all dead that look on her, and I'm to get your consent he may leave you.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Alas! pray tell him tho' 'twill break my very heart; yet what must be, must be, Marriages are made in Heaven, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Let me alone: but see where he comes breathless.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: News, news, news, news!

sp.speaker: Dia
sp.p: Mackerel, Mackerel, Mackerel, fresh come ashore.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Whe, how now, Mrs. Marinda! whe, you look blith and brisk upon't.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Whe ay, is not that better than louring, and pouting, and puling, which is troublesom to the living and vain to the Dead? for my own part, let my Husband laugh at me when I'm dead, so he smile upon me whilst I live: I love a chearful countenance in all conditions.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Ay, but to see a Woman whine, and yet the Devil a tear falls; mourn, and yet keep her cheeks full.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Ay, there's the Devil.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: And yet I was heartily afraid y faith that I shou'd a seen a Garland on that Beauty's Herse; but Time, Truth, Experience and variety, have great power over Woman-kind.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Well Sir, but to the business, the News you were so big with?

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Why, 'tis this: the Publick Sessions this day holden at the Old Baily has condemn'd poor Frank Friendly.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Hah! Whe Sir, he offered to produce Mr. Wellman at one Mr. Glisters a Goldsmiths.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: That's all one, when it came to the test Glister deny'd he ever saw or heard of him, and his own Confession hangs him without more witness, and with him Dashit the Vintner is condemn'd for Robbery, and several others.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: How? Dashit for Robbery? and was it prov'd against him?

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Only shrewd suspicions, 'tis thought he'l have a Pardon: a Cloak was stolen, that Cloak he had. The Justice was in Drink that committed him, the Judges severe and in haste, the Jury hungry, and so the Knave was cast; but hang him, he has cheated me with many an unmerciful Bill: but, Lord, to hear his mone, his wishes, his curses, his prayers, and his ill-tim'd Zeal, by my troth, they wou'd have made a Comedy. But, Sir, the Lady, the poor Lady you serve, and who betrayed Friendly, is sent to Newgate; Well, I'll take my Oath 'tis a lovely Gentlewoman, 'tis a thousand pities; they say she must be try'd the next Sessions.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Let me alone for a neat and seasonable lye; [aside.— how Sir, a Lady, pray, who mean ye?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: She that was here, Madam, and gave an account how Wellman was kill'd.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Heav'ns, his Sister! Mean you Wellman's Sister Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: How, Wellman's Sister?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Wellman's Sister, Madam?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Can you do less for an abandon'd Mistris than tell a handsom lye to get her a good Husband? Say 'tis so, or I'll make mischief.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: The Gentleman knows 'tis so: I told him she was of Quality.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: A very virtuous Maid; Heav'ns! that I had but a Brother that wou'd marry her, and take her part in defiance of the World! Nay Sister, we must in Honour visit her: poor Innocence!

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Hah! Wellman's Sister? Whe, look ye Madam, tho' you have not a Brother, I wou'd have you to know you have a Lover, that will do as much to serve you as any Lover in Christendom, and as for marrying her, for your sake, Madam, and to do the Lady good, I'de venture as far as Hercules, de ye see, or Alexander the Great, that I wou'd.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Most Heroically spoken, the Contents do almost break my heart, yet, Sir, to let you see I scorn to be out-done in Bravery, I'le— give you leave— to marry her; and I think that's a bold word.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Egad and so 'tis.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay if you are so resolv'd, and keep that Resolution, 'twill not be hard to bring the Lady off, so many Friends joyning to her party.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: For my part I'll dye to serve her.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: And so will I in blood, now I'm set on't,

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Come then, without Delay let's visit her,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Where? At New-gate Sister?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: At New-gate: Oh let not that Word fright you, because so many have gone to the Gallows from thence! martyr'd Innocence does often dye where Thieves and Robbers do; a Gallows may be sanctify'd, why not a Prison? Come Sir John your hand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And Sir I must beg yours.

div.stage: Great-gate. SCENE changes to the Front of New-gate at the Grate two or three Prisoners, one a beging, a Box hangs out.
[Begs in a low Voice, and crys the while.

sp.speaker: 1 Pris.
sp.p: Pray remember the poor Prisoners, the poor Prisoners, pray remember the poor Prisoners. ho, ho, ho!

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Dam ye for a Son of a Whore, how sneakingly do you beg— Remember the Poor— ye meeching Bitch, is that a Voice to dive to the Bottom of a Usurers Pocket, and fetch out Money in despight of his harden'd heart?— Remember the Poor? Pox of your snivelling, stand by ye Dog, and let me come to the Grate.

sp.speaker: 1 Pris.
sp.p: Alas, Mr. Shamock, me thinks we should have little Stomach to beg, I hear our Reprieves are out of Doors, and they talk of a Warrant for Execution, so that we may be hang'd to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Why you whining Cur, be hang'd to Morrow? whe then we have the more need to beg hard to day, that we may drink at parting; Sirrah beg me heartily and with a good impudent Grace, I'll beat out your Brains with your own Fetters.

sp.speaker: 1 Pris.
sp.p: Oh! hold, hold, spare my Life good Mr. Shamock.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: So, I see thou bear'st a Conscience, and wo't not cheat the Gallows of it's due.

sp.speaker: 1 Pris.
sp.p: Oh no Sir, I have too much Repentance to wish to dye so wickedly, as I have liv'd; I wou'd go out of the World like a good Christian however.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Was there ever such a chicken-hearted Son of a Whore? thou wert ever a lazy Rascal, and I remember when we were getting a painful Living on the Kings High-way, wou'dst sleep the while, yet wake to share the snack, and to be drunk for Joy of the Prize: Stand away and observe me now, with what a laudable Voice I'll move Compassion:
sp.stage: [Pulls off his Periwig, turns his Cravate behind, thrusts out his Head and begs in a canting Tone.
sp.p: Christians pitty the poor Prisoners of this loathsome and dismal Dungeon, and 'twill be restored unto you in tenfold; drop your Bounty into this little Box, the only Support, Relief, and Comfort of twenty wretched Souls.
Noble Sir, Remember the poor Prisoners:
sp.stage: [He pulls out a long Purse and puts in a two-pence.
sp.p: The Lord reward your noble Charity, and restore it to you forty and forty fold.

'tis an old Oliverian two-pence, a damn'd Commonwealths pair of Breeches, confound the mark and your good Worships Bounty, was this all the large Lethern Purse and your more large Conscience cou'd produce, wou'd I were worthy to have a Dive or two at your reverend Pockets, I wou'd ease 'em for you with a Pox.
Hah! Ladies alighted—

Most beautiful Ladies, dispense your noble Charity amongst twenty miserable Wretches, opprest with Hunger and Cold: Merciful and fair— pity the Miseries of unfortunate young men; whose few short hours of Life they've left, shall be imploy'd in Prayers for you our noble Benefactors: Oh remember the Poor!
Sweet Lady, Heaven reward your Beauty with eternal Bloom and numberless Adorers.
sp.stage: [Pulls up the Box, they go in.
sp.p: Hah Gold! 'tis Gold by Jove.
Nay, now a short Life and a merry, we'l have it all in drink Boys, and when the Hour comes, dye like Hero's, sing the Psalm merrily, and then— be hang'd till we're sober.

sp.speaker: 1 Pris.
sp.p: Ah! Mr. Shamock 'tis a long Nap we shall take e're we wake again.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: No matter, then we shall not be dry next Morning.

sp.speaker: 1 Pris.
sp.p: Oh this is sad jesting— Oh, Oh, Oh!

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Here's a cowardly Rogue, now Plague on him, he's a shame to the noble Function of Padding: Sirrah, you shall have no Drink, 'tis thrown away upon the Rascal.

sp.speaker: 3 Pr.
sp.p: Drink? rot him, let him lap salt Water from his Eyes, like a mangy Dog as he is.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Come, come, lets in and drink.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Mr. Shamock, you must come down to your Devotion, here's a Parson come; Mr. Ordinary's sick; come away.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Pox o' your Ceremonies, a man cannot be hang'd in Peace for your Parson, and your paultry praying— but come, hang't since we must obey silly Customs, let's down, and then— to drink, my hearts— go, get ye down.

div.head: SCENE the inside of the Prison.
div.stage: Enter Friendly in Irons, with Sir Lyonel, Mr. Dashet in Irons, Mrs. Dashet weeping by him, Nan and others: Trick-well disguis'd like a Parson, seeming exhorting 'em: Corina and Mrs. Dunwel snivelling.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No Sir, I do not blush, nor are my cheeks grown, pale, tho' I'm condemn'd to dye a shameful death.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: No kind of Death is shameful but the Cause.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Which I well know is none, Heaven is my witness, none.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Ah! you are happy Sir!— happy to quit the World in Innocence, for Innocence— is a most heavenly thing— for Sir, Innocence is all in all; Innocence is—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Very impertinent in your mouth, Sir,— you ought to have the manners to believe a dying man has other bus'ness— than to give ear to what you say; go preach to the Rabble, Sir, I'm not at leisure.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Ah!— what is sinful man— speak to him, Sir, to think upon his Soul, his precious Soul; ah, his too precious Soul—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Perhaps I'm not of your perswasion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Hah! Heaven forbid— I hope you'r not a Papist Sir.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: If I am, Sir, what then?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What then? whe then Sir, guilty or not guilty, you deserve to dye, and I'll prove it, and stand to't.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Prethee leave us, we are serious.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Leave yee, yes faith, 't: you are not worth a Groat.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: But is there Sir no hopes of a Reprieve?

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: I'll warrant you Sir, I've Interest enough for that.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Upon my Honour, Sir, Wellman is but mislodg'd, and l've already satisfied yee how I came to say what I did of his Death to that fair false one,— sure some Lethargy has seiz'd him, that he appears not, or else he's mad, it cannot be unkindness, and it wou'd grieve you, Sir, to see me dye, and after find me innocent.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: By th' Mass, and so it wou'd, Sir; therefore I'll to Court about your Reprieve immediately; nor need you doubt my Diligence or Success;— but why, thou beauteous Hypocrite, didst thou betray him thus?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I will not answer thee: I own my guilt, and am asham'd and angry at my Destiny: Were Wellman dead, I could endure the rest, but would not live to see him live another's.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Well Sir, fare ye well till anon.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.l: Oh! how I hate what once I so ador'd!
He that's born well, and Nobly Educated,
Blest with an honest Fame, and worthy Friend,
And wou'd with desperate over-sight love all
And land himself upon this fatal shore,
Let him ne're kill, or steal, but love a Whore.
sp.stage: Enter Wellman, Marinda, Sir Iohn, Ample and Shatter, Diana.
sp.l: — hah!— what do I see?
Now everlasting Darkness cover me
From that dear injur'd killing sight, Diana.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p:
Nay, do not hide your Face, or turn away— I'm wondrous glad to know where a Maid may find ye when she has need of you; and tho' these Chains are something easier than those of Matrimony, yet, like a malicious Woman, I am for proposing a change; faith, what d'ye think on't? dare ye venture? methinks
'twere no ungrateful Leap from the Gallows into a fair young Ladies Arms?— wou'd you not rather cry, Drive away Carman?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Oh! do not mock my miseries, Diana!

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: By this hand, not I; You may remember, I swore never to marry, till the man I lik'd cou'd give me proofs he was a man; you bow'd, and blush'd, and talk'd of Maidenheads, and modestly protested your Virginity; oh, filthy in a man! a man of sense too!— but you'r improv'd, I hear, grown wise of late, and given me proofs you are no Block-head; and I, to keep my word, am come to challenge you;— and to put you out of all these hanging apprehensions, know Wellman's alive.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: How! Wellman alive?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: My dear, unkind, have you dealt well with me?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: I was resolv'd I wou'd be quits with you for getting my Mistress from me; which by the way I beg you wou'd forgive. I've a Design to marry her to Empty.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: She is a Woman, and I scorn to injure her.
— And can you, Madam, except this Criminal in Chains?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: The sooner for that reason, with my Father's leave, I have a good hank upon you when you're insolent, to upbraid ye with the place from whence I had ye.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He cannot but commend your Passion for him.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I am asham'd to be so much oblig'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, leave the shame to her.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.p: Shame, I laugh at it, and wou'd have believ'd none to have marry'd Friendly under the Gallows— therefore take my hand, and bind the bargain.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Thou art a Noble Creature, and I am thine forever.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: By Heaven, Corina, it was not want of Love, my Fortune did depend upon my Marriage, but when I saw the Woman destin'd for me, I must confess I felt new flames possess me, without extinguishing the old, and I resolv'd to love her virtuously, and hold an honest Friendship still with thee— to raise thee up above the Worlds contempt, the fickle favours of unconstant man, and love thee as my Siste.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
What pow'rful Charms dwell in thy tender language! thou melt'st my rage with every softening look, and lead'st me
a tame Captive to thy will;— I am still all thine, dispose me as thou pleasest.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: This Knight, Corina, then resolve to marry, I'll make thy Fortune equal to his Quality, the man is honest, young, and Master of himself. He thinks thou art my Sister— nor will I ever undeceive him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Well— since I must lose you, and am by your Commands obliged to Life, no matter how forlorn and wretched 'tis—

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: By my troth, Sir, you have left her like a man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Sir Iohn, you are my Friend, and this my onely Sister, for whom I know you have a Passion; and since Mrs. Diana is dispos'd of, I am resolv'd you shall not be disappointed of a Lady. Take her, and trust my Friendship for her Fortune, 'twill not be inconsiderable.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Fortune Sir! I scorn she shou'd owe her Ladiship to any Fortune but what my single Honour can give.

— therefore Madam, I am your Knight, your Champion, your most humble Husband and obedient Servant, Iohn Empty, Baronet: but good Brother, let us make haste out of this scandalous place, it puts me so damnably in mind of mortality, it will spoil my Wedding-night.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Ay Sir, as soon as Friendly's discharg'd.

sp.speaker: Marin.
sp.p: You must give me leave to call This while Trickwell is seeming exhorting the Prisoners, and picking their pockets, Sir John. and Wellm. looking at Trick. & the Pris'ners. your Sister too, for I must love and serve all that love Wellman.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Madam, the Generous Pattern that you have set me, I shall be proud to follow.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Hah, Sure that Wench I know,— 'tis she— whe how how now, Nan, what brought thee hither?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: 'Fore Gad e'en my kind heart, Mr. Wellman, Love, villanous Love!

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: Hah, Love! whe, what a pox, is that become a hanging matter in our Age?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: If 'twere, your Neck's in no great danger.

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: Good Lord, what I warrant you think I was never in love then? yes faith have I, and have felt your Flames and Fires, and Inclinations, and Wamblings, as often as any He that wears a head.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Then you are the first Fool I ever knew inspir'd.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: spare him Nan, he's my Brother, but prethee say how came Love to bring thee to this fatal end?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Fatal! 'tis my Glory— and egad my Statue and History ought to be added to the Gallery of Heroick Women— why you have hear'd I suppose, that my Husband was condemn'd last Sessions, Mr Shamock.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: What the famous Padder? is he thy Husband?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Yes Faith, he had a Reprieve, but now the Warrant's sign'd for Execution, and he is to be hang'd to morrow.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Well what's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Whe faith, we have liv'd lovingly hitherto together, and we'll e'ne dye as lovingly, for I am resolv'd to be hang'd honestly with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: Honestly hang'd— how so?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Whe I'll tell you Sir, when the Tidings came to me of poor Iack's being apprehended, I soon knew which way the World wou'd go with him; I ne're snivel'd and nouted like a feeble Woman for the matter, but e'ne resolv'd bravely to take a Turn at Tyburn with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: Lord have Mercy upon us.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: In order thereunto, what does me I, but hearing of a Fellow that had lost a parcel of Goods of value, but goes my ways to him, accuses my self for the Thief, was sent to Newgate, and to my great Joy and Satisfaction, was condemn'd with honest Iack efaith: On my Soul, Mr. Wellman, I trembled for Fear I thou'd have been acquitted, but the honest Jury took Pity on me, and brought me in Guilty. When the Devil wou'd any of your Wives of Quality have show'd this conjugal Constancy?

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: Lord deliver me, what a wicked World is this, that People shou'd have the face to confess their Villainies! she confesses all now, and some are hang'd and confess nothing.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: And wo't thou be so good natur'd to take a Turn with him at the Gallows?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: With as much Joy as e're I kiss'd him.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Whe this is the most admirable Proof of Love, I ever heard off.

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: Proof of Love, proof of the Devil, Man, what to be slain at Tyburn for Love? whe 'tis most damnable and as nonsensical as to be hang'd for Religion.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I find by your Principles that you'l keep out of Harms way.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Nay o'my Conscience, I shall ne're increase the Number of the noble Army of the Martyrs.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Nan, where are you, here's the Fellow has brought home our Coffin.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Let him bring't in my dear, you shall see Mr. Wellman, what a Device I have found out, never to part with dear Jack: I have bespoke a Coffin to hold us both.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: How a Coffin? Lord have Mercy upon's, how great the Devil is with this Woman! but what care have you taken of your Soul all this while?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: That's the Business of Mr. Ordinary, he has so much a year allow'd him for managing that Affair, and has undertaken mine: Come bring in the Coffin.

div.stage: Enter Fellow with a Coffin, They look on't.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Whe, what a Coffin's here? Is this a Coffin fit for Christians?— D'ye see, and all pitch't within too, ye Dog, we shall stick to't, a pox on ye for a nasty Son of a Whore.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Bless me, sure these Reprobates never think of going to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Ay! I gave him two broad pieces in hand too, and two more I have in my Pocket to give him—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Which I must be acquainted with.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: But he shall be damn'd e're he be so well paid.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Besides, Sirrah, you might have had the Manners to have lin'd it with a little Bays this cold Weather, but you have neither Conscience nor fore-cast.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Lord! Brother Wellman, I believe some Priests have been tampering with 'em, they are so wicked.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Ha, Ha, Ha! a notable Observation.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: I'de forgot too, I'll lay my Head to a Halter, this Coffin will not hold us both.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Hark ye Friend, don't lay with him, for he's oth' surer side.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Yes my Dear, as for that I believe we may make Shift, 'tis but my laying my Arm under thy Head, and thou thine over my Breast, and we shall lye as snug these cold nights—

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Whe the Devil's in these People.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: But I have a cursed Misfortune befallen me.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: What's that, my dear Betty?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: The Whore the Laundress, who had all the Linnen I was to be buryed in, like an ungrateful Baggage, knowing I was to be hang'd, and she to have no more of my Custom, has pawn'd all, my lac'd Linnen too; so that, dear Jack, I shall come to thy Arms but scurvily equipt to morrow.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Lets arrest her. Lord, Lord, that People shou'd have no Conscience nor Honesty in 'em: what will this wicked World come to.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Ay! and to rob the Gallows too, unmerciful Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Young Woman, young Woman, this is no time to think of Trifles, and gew gaws; the best dress is that of Repentance, let your Conscience be clean and neat within, and no matter for Lace and Tawdrums; dress up your Soul I say.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Whe what a Pox have we here?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: One who has preacht better Doctrine to your Ladyship e're now, [and] one who am appointed to put you in mind of your long home.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Whe ye Fool you, have I been taking such pains to prepare my self for this Journey, and need your Advice in the Devils name? get ye gone ye canting Rascal, here's honest Jack can teach me how to dye worth a Legion of you formal Gown-men.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Gad thou'rt a noble Lass.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: In Troth and so she is, 'tis Pity she shou'd be damn'd.

div.stage: Trick. goes to Dashet, Betty to the Joyner.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Well Sirrah, here is your two pieces more, because I scorn to be worse than my word— [Feels in her Pocket. hah! my money's gone— what's the meaning of this? I had 'em and the two pieces for Jack Catch too in my Pocket when I came down.

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Whe what a Pox have we Thieves amongst our selves? this is fine doings efaith.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Hang't let it go, they are some poor Devils that wanted it: go out and wait till I go up, and I'll pay you.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Or let him call again to Morrow in the Evening—

div.stage: Trick. talking this while to Dashet, he making Grimaces of Wo, and crying and wringing his hands, Mrs. Dashet crying by him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dashet.
sp.p: Well Husband, this is a very comfortable man.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: He is so. But, good Mr. Parson, leave my Soul a little while to it self, I pray, and let us have a little of your counsel concerning my Body. I owe Mr. Glister the Goldsmith 40 l. and suppose, Mr. Parson, when I am going to Execution he shou'd be so unneighbourly as to set a Ser jeant upon my back— 'twas for a Bowl—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Ah! trouble not thy self, my Christian Brother with transitory matters, but have an Eye— an Eye I say to the main chance— [picking his pocket. I'll warrant your shoulders; but as for your neck— Plinius Secundus, or Marcus Tullius Cicero, or some body says; that a threefold Cord is hardly broken.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: A very Learned man this— well, I am not the first honest man that has been hang'd, and I hope shall not be the last.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: True Sir, therefore have a righteous Stomach: for you perhaps may sup in Heaven to morrow.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Alas, Sin! I have no stomach to it at all Sir,— please you to take my Trencher, I never eat at night.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dash.
sp.p: Ah, Husband, I little thought you shou'd have had need to have thought of Heaven so soon: oh!— had you been hang'd deservedly 'twou'd ne're have troubled me: for there's many an innocent man has been hang'd deserv'dly,— but to be cast away for nothing— oh,— oh.—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Comfort your self, good Mistris, moderate Grief is decent, you'l shortly be a Widow, and I'm a Batchelor; I'll come and visit ye, and give you Christian consolation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dash.
sp.p: Ah, Sir! you shall be heartily welcome, and pray make haste.— oh— oh—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Well,— I do here make my Confession before all good Christian People, and do declare— that if I owe any man any thing, I do heartily forgive him.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: In truth, Religiously spoken. Whe, this is something.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: But— but, if any manowes me any thing, let him pay my Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: A good reason too y faith.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: There— are— the Writings of that Rogue's Estate who has brought me to this untimely End— dear Writings to me, God knows.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dash.
sp.p: Where had you these?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I took 'em out yesterday, thinking to have carry'd 'em to my Lawyers, in order to taking the forfeiture of 'em: now thou may'st do't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Da.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Husband, I'll warrant'ye, I shall be diligent.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: And now, good Yoke-fellow, take leave of thy honest and true Dashet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dash.
sp.p: No, Husband, an't please the Lord I'll not leave you now,— I'll see you hang'd first—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Hah, my writings! now for a trick of dexterity to retrieve those, and I'm a man again— [aside] but Brother, you must remember your sins too, and iniquities; you must consider you have been a Broacher of prophane Vessels, you have made us drunk with the juice of the Whore of Babylon: for whereas good Ale, Perry, Syder, and Metheglin, were the true Ancient British and Trojan Drinks, you have brought in Popery, meer Popery— French and Spanish Wines, to the subversion, staggering, and overthrowing of many a good Protestant Christian;— oh! remember the Sins of the Cellar, beloved, the Mid-night sins that have been unsavoury to the tasts of your Customers, when you put the change upon 'em: remember your double scorings and long Bills, ah, remember your long Bills.
sp.stage: [this while he picks Mrs. Dashets pocket of the Writings.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: This is that Rogue Trickwell.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Ah! I confess, I confess, and forgive. [cryes.— has any heard of one Trickwell?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Trickwell; yes, I know him well: a very honest Religious man, and an unright Dealer with his Neighbours, and their Wives speak well of him.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I'll take it upon my Death he's the cause of my hanging, but I heartily forgive him; and if he wou'd but yet come forth and save me, I wou'd set him free from the Law, and discharge him for injuring me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: And wou'd you from the bottom of your Soul forgive him all his cheats and Rogueries?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I wou'd, and be bound in a thousand pound Bond to save him from the Law: ah! but 'tis impossible—

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Why look ye, Sir,— behold, your worshipful Friend and humble Servant Thomas Trickwell.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Hah! discovered by Mr. Wellman.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Trickwell!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Now bawling Mr. Dashet.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Who wou'd have look't for a Wolf in Sheeps cloathing? or a Knave in a Parson's Gown?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No railing Dashet, if you do, I'l swear against you yet.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Ay do, and damn your Soul.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What with a little Perjury? the Lord have Mercy on our Age then: No, no Sir, I'll retrieve you from the Gallows, but as for your Goods and Moneys it must go towards the use of my two hundred pound a year, which you have kept me from this two years, and of which now, thanks to my Dexterity, I stand again possest.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: How my Writings gone?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Thank God you're so rid of them, for I had been an eternal Rent charge upon you else, if I had not hang'd you: you know you had 'em for a little damn'd ballderdash Wine—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Well, I'de better loose my Writings than my Life.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Hold Trickwell;— yonder Woman I have been oblig'd to, and you have had Relief from— no Writings nor Pardon under marrying Mrs. May here—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, what a Bawd?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: The better Sirrah, she has a good Calling then, when all fails.

sp.speaker: Dun.
sp.p: Gods Blessing of your heart, Sir.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: No grumbling, do't or I'le deliver:— remember Sirrah how you used my Mistress last night, and had the Impudence to rival me—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well Sir of two Evils I'll chuse this— give me thy hand Moll, thou'st been a loving Soul I must confess.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: So there's some Revenge, I cou'd even cry for Joy now,

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dash.
sp.p: And so cou'd I too, if I knew for what.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: Here, where's Mr. Friendly— here's your Reprieve Sir, Hah! Marinda and Diana!

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Yet with their Husbands Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: How, How?— hah! Mr. Wellman alive? and with Mr. Friendly— God bless ye, God bless ye all, I'm glad on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Ay Sir, and I am maryed to this Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: I'm glad of that too.
Here Mrs. Betty, where are you? Here's a Reprieve come for you:

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Hah a Reprieve! What Devil ow'd me this malicious Spight, a Reprieve— dam thee, thou ill, thou ominous looking Dog, ever the Messenger of Hellish Tidings: Oh! I cou'd tear thy hated Tongue out— Rogue—

sp.speaker: Sham.
sp.p: Nay, dear, better be patient, and if we must part.—

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.l: Art thou turn'd cruel too, and preachest Patience?
Patience with Life— no, I defie my Fate—
Scorning to live without thee thou shalt see,
I'll find a thousand ways to dye with thee.—

sp.speaker: Sir Ly.
sp.p: By 'th Mass a hearty Wench I'll warrant her, but come let's away: good Boys let's home and Dance, but first give Money to these poor Wretches.
From this dire place many to Death have gone,
But to be marry'd, very rarely one.
